35.heading: Pampa.
35.title: "Bahubali : He Gave Up His Empire to Learn the Truth"
35.author: script, Subba Rao ; illustrations, Dilip Kadam ; editor, Anant Pai
35.appears_in: p. 1-30 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 683 (1974, 2009 printing).
notes: (Epics & Mythology)

Summary from back cover: "Bharata, king of Ayodhya, had an overriding ambition to become king of kings. He set about subduing every kingdom possible including those of his brothers. The only person to oppose his arrogance was his half-brother, Bahubali, who defeated Bharata in single combat. However, Bahubali abdicated all claims to the throne and left for the forests to meditate. Centuries later Chavundaraya, a commander-in-chief of the Ganga dynasty build a 57 feet high statue of Bahubali at Shravana Belagola. This story has been taken from Pampa's Adi Purana and Panchabana's Bhujabali Charita."

78.heading: Pan-Pipes.
78.title: "The Mystery of the Super-Batman!"
78.author: Craig Boldman, writer ; Alex Saviuk, penciller ; Karl Kesel, inker ; Ben Oda, letterer ; D'Angelo, colorist ; Julius Schwartz, editor
notes: Summary (by Mary Walker): Lana Lang reports on mysterious sightings of a 'super-Batman'. Kent calls Bruce Wayne and leaves a message with Alfred that he has a good reason for what he is doing and will explain later. He recalls how Lana had some Pan-pipes which her father found with a statue of the god and how he experienced an excruciating pain when she blew on them. Later he looks in the mirror and finds he has grown horns. He realizes that the syrinx, or pipes, may be the cure but he has to find them because they have been stolen. To hide what has happened he adopts Batman's cowl and cape in place of his own cape. He uses the horns to capture the superstitious thief before the spell dissipates taking the horns with them. He tells Bruce about the episode and asks, "How do you ever manage to scare anyone in that get-up of yours?"

110.heading: Panama, Chico.
110.title: "The Whisper Mystery"
110.author: by Daniel Torres
110.appears_in: p. 41-48 in Heavy Metal, v. 9, no. 5 (Aug. 1985).
notes: "Catch Up (from p. 39): While working on the new Sam Norton episode for SF magazine, Armando Mistral is visited by his old friend Chico Panama, a womanizer and a cheat. Unable to get rid of Panama, Mistral hotfoots it over to Montebahia for a bit of r&r, where he runs into Archie Cooper, a Chandleresque detective, and a bunch of thugs fighting it out. Cooper is murderered by a bunch of human-size lizards, and Chop Jones (the man behind this whole drug-related mess in the first place) pays Mistral a visit."

notes: Summary: The Jonah goes through the Panama Canal, and when it's far behind the crew is released from the hold.

130.heading: Panama Canal.

130.author: Roy Crane

132.heading: Panama Canal.
132.title: "I Hear We're Going Through the Panama Canal"
132.author: Roy Crane
132.appears_in: p. 166 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Three years aboard the Jonah is a 'miserable prospect,' but there is a ray of hope.
Eleventh in a sequence of 107 daily strips reprinted here.

133.heading: Panama Canal.
133.title: "Lolanda, and the Big Boom Bomb"
133.author: Fran Matera
notes: Begins: "We find Dickie, Dan and John Henry leaving the Panama Canal on their way to Lolanda."

Summary: Fish are dying and people are sick as well on the Micronesian island of Lolanda, and people are blaming the American atomic bomb tests. Actually a would-be dictator named Rogar is poisoning the water. Lolanda is also the name of the chief's daughter, who is married to John, and of the sailboat the heroes arrive on.

134.heading: Panama Canal.
134.title: "The Phony Sailor" 2 p. text in Fightin' Navy, no. 74
134.author: [No author]
notes: Begins: "Joe Greene and Gene Minor left the restaurant and turned to the docks where the launch was waiting to take them back to their ship, the U.S.S. Richmond which was on its way to the Far East, but before passing through the locks of the Canal, had given liberty to its crew in Panama."
